titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Return’d to Boston this morning, with my wife and child— Mr: Shaw came into town with Mr: Black— Quincy called at my Office.— Evening at home.

2. Spent the day at my Office, reading Park and Blackstone— Mr: Boylston and Mr: Benjn: Shaw called there— Recd: two letters from my brother Thomas, with his acct: and money.— Pass’d the evening with Mrs: Wilson, and Mrs: Dobell— General Knox, Mr: Morton, Mr: Otis and their ladies; Mrs: Swan, Mrs: G. Blake, and several other ladies and gentlemen were there— Political topics of conversation— Conversed likewise with Mr: J. Vaughan upon subjects of literature and science— Home at 10— Jos: Hall there— Return’d this eveg: from Philadelphia.

3. Snow, with various intervals, the greater part of the day— Called in the forenoon at Quincy’s Office— J. Gardner was at mine— Read but little— Mrs: Adams went to the play with Mr: Shaw, and part of Mr: Smith’s family.— The club was at my house.— Cleared up cold at night.— Deposited at the Bank of the U.S. here, the 1900 dollars I received yesterday from my brother.

4. Employed almost the whole morning in domestic affairs, and did not get to my office untill past 11. Mr: Parkman had sent us a ticket for the assembly— But we concluded not to go— Spent the evening at home; read to Mrs: A. a few pages of Locke on Education.

5. The weather has become very cold— I pass’d the day at my office, and the evening with the Society— Frazier read us an outline of Churchman’s new magnetical theory, and his method of ascertaining the longitude by the variations of the magnet— Mrs: Adams spent the evening at Mrs: Jonn: Davis’s.

6. Hall and Quincy were at my office in the forenoon. Dined at Mr: Babcock’s with a company of about twenty gentlemen— Stayed there till 7. in the evening— Remainder of the eve at home— The weather very cold— Reaumur’s thermometer at 7 this morning was at 15 degrees below 0— I am much dissatisfied with myself this day— Ashamed of my own weakness of character, and inability to accomplish my resolutions.

7. Attended meeting— Heard Mr: Smith, professor of divinity at Dartmouth College in the forenoon; and Mr: Emerson in the afternoon— Evening at home— Read further in Locke on Education— Mr: Smith’s daughter Mary this morning, badly burnt by her clothes catching fire— Rain and thaw.

8. At the probate office this morning and should have return’d again in the afternoon, but did not. Called on Mr: Parsons to consult him upon Boylston Adams’s case.— At Dr: Welsh’s in the afternoon but he was not at home. He called at our house in the evening— Walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home— Continued reading Locke on education to Mrs: A— Settled Mr: Foster’s Account this morning.

9. The Supreme Judicial Court, commenced their session in this town— Judge Payne delivered the charge to the grand-jury— Dr: Lathrop made the prayer— I Dined at Mr: Allen’s, the Sheriff’s, with the Governor, the Judges, and several other gentlemen of this town.— There was a cry of fire in the afternoon— Spent the evening at Dr: Jackson’s, with the Society for the study of natural philosophy— Dr: Prince was there— He came from Salem, and brought our electrical apparatus with us— He shewed and explained to us the various instruments and their uses, and manner of managing them—untill 10 o’clock— There was a light fall of snow which made the evening not peculiarly favourable for electrical experiments— But most of those he made succeeded sufficiently for our purposes.

10. Mr: Boylston called upon me this morning, and had some conversation with me upon the subject of his affairs. Attended at the Supreme Court, which adjourn’d early. Dined with Mr: John Gore, in a company of about twenty Gentlemen— Spent the evening and supp’d at Mr: T. C. Amory’s, with a number of Gentlemen and Ladies— It was near midnight before we reached home:— Played Cards part of the evening.

11. Went to Mr: Boylston’s lodgings, and he opened to me the nature of his controverted affairs here—particularly his demands as Administrator of T. Boylston, and Attorney to the Assignees of Lane, Son and Fraser, against the estate of the late Governor Gill— Afterwards attended at the Supreme Court— Mr: W. Smith asked me if I would act upon a Commission of bankruptcy, judge Davis having it in contemplation to appoint a second one in this town— The present Commissioners have more business than they can attend to— I told him I would act, if the judge thought proper to appoint me— The other two Commissioners he said would be judge Dawes, and J. Hall.— Dined at Mr: Smith’s, with a company of fifteen or sixteen gentlemen— In the eveg: Mrs
Mrs: Apthorp called and took up Mrs: Adams, and we went to the Ball— We had an invitation for the season from the managers, but this was the first time we have attended— The hall was thin—not more than forty ladies— I danced a couple of dances— At ten there was a supper— About four fifths of the company were unknown to me— New comers since I resided here before, and was a member of the assembly. We came home, a little before midnight.

12. Attended an Auction of Mr Marston’s furniture, but found nothing there to purchase— At the Supreme Court which soon adjourn’d— Call’d at the Registry of Deeds— Then at the probate Office— Then on Mr: Perkins Nichols the register of probate— Remainder of the morning at my office.— Dined at Mr: Gardner Greene’s, with a company of ladies and gentlemen.— He has good accommodations— In the evening attended at the Society, and heard Doctor Jackson begin upon the subject of electricity.

13. Our servant man William, was yesterday taken very ill with the meazles— Mrs: Adams much alarmed for the child. Sent him to Mrs: Smith’s in the morning; and home again before night. Mr: Boylston called upon me in the morning. Dexter came into town from Quincy— The family there too, partly sick.— I got my deed from Dr: Parker, and my own mortgage to him, from the Registry of deeds— Examined at the probate office, the copy and probate of Mrs: Howard’s Will— Afterwards at my office untill near 3. Dined at Mr: Saml: Perkins’s; with a company of Gentlemen, and two young ladies, Miss Hiller, and Miss Cushing, with Mrs: Perkins— Politics after dinner. We sat untill 9 in the evening without starting.— I came home and then went for Mrs: Adams who pass’d the evening at Mrs: Smith’s.

14. Heard Dr: Lathrop in the morning, upon the distinction between the good and the righteous man—and Mr: Clap in the afternoon— An exhortation to religious life address’d to youth— Walk’d in the Mall;—but not long, the walking being very bad.— J. Hall called and spent a couple of hours with us— Read to Mrs: A. further in Locke on Education.

15. The late lieutenant Governor Phillips was this day buried.— The bells were toll’d and minute guns fired here, and a sermon was preached on the occasion which the legislature attended— The Supreme Court likewise adjourned early on the same account— I took out a couple of citations from the probate office.— At my own office till dinner time, and all the afternoon— Walk’d in the Mall, although the streets are deep— In the evening continued reading to Mrs: A—Locke’s treatise.

16. Attended the session of the Supreme Court morning and afternoon— Prisoner’s arraigned— A trial in the afternoon, of a civil cause— Walk’d in the Mall— Finished reading Locke on Education this evening.
17. There was a criminal prosecution tried in the forenoon; and two civil actions in the afternoon— In the evening, I called upon Quincy, and went with him to the club at Judge Davis’s.

18. Trial of Kelly for a forgery of bank bills; but the case against him was not made out— In the evening we had a meeting of the Society, and made some further electrical experiments— Mr: Kirkland read the synopsis— The evening was very cold and favourable for excitation of the instrument— The principal object of the lecture was to examine the various parts of the apparatus— Judge Davis & Mr: Williams were not present.— Mrs: A— at the Assembly.

19. Trial of a civil action which took up the whole day— I called on Mr: William Shaw— Spent the evening and supp’d at Mr: Otis’s— Company of Ladies and Gentlemen.— Play’d whist, with Mrs: Knox, Mr: G. Greene and Mr: T. Perkins. Weather very cold— Home at Midnight.

20. Mr: Shaw from Quincy called at my office with Mr: Parkman, respecting the citation issued to him from the probate Court.— I got the papers from the U.S. Loan office—transferr’d 2000 dollars 8 per cents to Charles Rogers; gave the certificates to Mr: Cleland, and received for them 2240 dollars in bank bills of him— Mr: Vinal engaged me in his cause to be argued next Tuesday, on an indictment for a libel upon Mr: Dana, the chief Justice— Judge Dawes called at my office and had some conversation with me respecting the contemplated second commission of bankruptcy. Attended court the rest of the morning, untill their adjournment— Walk’d with Quincy in the mall, till dinner time— Spent the afternoon in Otis’s office reading books upon the question of evidence in Vinal’s case— Eveg: at home— Read Locke’s life.

21. Heard a Mr: Clark Brown preach for Mr: Emerson, who is gone upon a journey— In the afternoon I went with Mrs: Adams to the Chapel, and heard Mr: Freeman— Mrs: Swan and her daughter Mrs: Howard came home with us. They paid us but a short visit— Mr: Shaw dined with us.— Dr: and Mrs: Welsh and John, Mr: & Mrs: Smith, and his sister Betsey spent part of the evening with us.— Remainder of it I began to read to Mrs: A—Locke’s Essay on the human understanding.— At 11. at night I went to Mr: Smith’s— He had summoned me to patrol the streets with him this night— This is done by a vote of the town— Deacon Morrill, Mr: Mason, Mr: Hunt and young Appleton who lives with Mr: Smith, went with us. We went round in two parties four times in the course of the night— The first part of the night was pleasant; but a severe snow storm came on before morning— At 1/2 past four, we broke up.

22. The Snow storm continued with extreme violence the whole of this day— I called at the probate Office, where Mr: Gray appeared for M’Intire— The Supreme Court met and adjourned on account of the weather— Quincy called at my office— I met him walking in the Mall last evening and went home with him; where I look’d into his State Trials and some other books— At my desire he sent me several of them this morning.— Mr: Vinal called at my house in the afternoon and gave me some minutes for his approaching trial— I went to Otis’s office and look’d over the books again— Evening at home reading, in Locke’s Essay.

23. The weather at length, in the night cleared up cold— The Snow has fallen several feet deep, but very much drifted and banked, from the violence of the wind— This morning the trial of Mr: Vinal came on; and after lasting the whole day, Mr: Davis the Solicitor General had not finished opening the cause on the part of Government. The day was spent in argument to questions of evidence— Mrs: Adams dined at Mr: B. Joy’s— I sent an excuse. After she came home I read a little in Locke’s Essay.

24. The Court this morning advised the Attorney & Sollicitor General, not to proceed in the prosecution of Vinal, upon the weak evidence they had produced— They agreed therefore to leave the cause to the Jury without further argument on either side— The Jury acquitted him— A trial of a civil action next came on, and took up the remainder of the day.— Evening with the Club at Judge Dawes’s— The weather this morning was very cold Reamur’s Thermometer at 15. degrees below 0.

25. Snow, the greatest part of the day— Attended the Court— There were several trials upon Indictments.— But all the defendants acquitted; and generally for want of evidence— In the afternoon one action of a civil nature was commenced; but broke off in the middle— club at Judge Dawes’s, where we I spent the Evening at I went and returned with Mr: Smith home and read in Locke’s Essay.

26. Rain and thaw; which came on so suddenly that the streets were rendered almost impassable— The snow which in many places was three feet deep, yielding every where under the foot, or forming into a slippery cake of ice. I had great difficulty in getting from home to the Court-house, and sat there the whole morning with wet feet. The Court adjourned over untill to-morrow— Judge Sullivan invited me to go home and dine with him; but I declined— We were to have spent the evening with Jonathan Amory, my old classmate; but were obliged to send an excuse— I was not out after dinner— Dr: Welsh here this morning to see Betsey Newcomb, who has just broke out with the meazles.

27. Weather Somewhat colder than yesterday— Snow, the greater part of the day. Walking in the Streets still very bad. Court sat till near 3 o’clock— Tried one cause, and began, but could not finish a second— After dinner I did not go from home— We were to have spent the evening at Mr: J. T. Apthorp’s, but the death of his uncle Doctor Bulfinch which happened yesterday, made him send an excuse for remitting the party— Evening as usual.

28. Weather still bad— Snowy day— Heard Mr Emerson in the forenoon and Mr Kirkland after dinner. Concluded the third volume of Tillotson, and his controversial treatise called the rule of faith.— Continued reading Locke’s Essay in the Evening.

Day. Rise between 6 and 8 o’clock— Read in Adams’s Essays on electricity till 9. Breakfast— Attend at the sittings of the Supreme Court, till 1. or 2. Home to dinner— At Court again untill 6 or 7. in the evening.— At Club, in Company or at home reading to my wife untill 10 or 11. o’clock.— Falling off from my morning hours.
